tit.cmt: An explanation/translation is usually provided in the text itself rather than in the title.

sen.j: 狛犬（こまいぬ、中国語：石獅子、英語：imperial guardian lion）とは、犬に似た想像上の獣の像である。
sen.e: A Komainu ("石獅子" in Chinese and "imperial guardian lion" in English) is an imaginary beast that looks like a dog.
A komainu ("石獅子" in Chinese and "imperial guardian lion" in English) is an imaginary mythical beast that resembles a dog and lion mixed together.
sen.cmt: The Japanese, and consequently the English translation, seem a little illogical to me. They basically say that something called an imperial guardian lion looks like a dog. This cell was already done, but I added " imaginary mythical beast that resembles a dog and lion mixed together" (Bob Licciardi)
sen.e: A komainu ("石獅子" in Chinese and "imperial guardian lion" in English) is an imaginary mythical beast that resembles a dog and lion mixed together.

sen.j: 神社や寺院の入口の両脇、あるいは本殿・本堂の正面左右などに1対で置かれている。
sen.e: Komainu are placed in pair on the both sides of the entrance to the shrine or temple or the façade of its main hall.
Komainu are placed in pairs, one of each on either side of the entrance to a shrine or temple or the façade of its main hall.
sen.cmt: This cell in Trans 2 was already done by someone else, but I saw an opportunity to clarify it further so, I added "one of each" (by Bob Licciardi)
sen.e: Komainu are placed in pairs, one of each on either side of the entrance to a shrine or temple or the façade of its main hall.

sen.j: なお、厳密には「獅子・狛犬」と呼ぶのが正しいとされている。
sen.e: Strictly speaking, it would be more appropriate to refer to them as "Shishi/komainu".
Strictly speaking, these should be referred to as "Shishi komainu" (literally, "lion dogs").
Strictly speaking, these should be referred to as "Shishi komainu" (literally, "lion dogs").

sen.j: 名称は高麗（こま、異国）の犬という意味とされる説がある。
sen.e: According to some scholars, its name suggests that Komainu is a dog from Koma (Goryeo).
According to some scholars, its name suggests that Komainu is a dog from Koma (Goryeo).
According to some scholars, its name suggests that Komainu is a dog from Koma (Goryeo).

sen.j: これは朝鮮経由で入ってきたためであるとされる。
sen.e: This is because they are considered to have come through Korea.
This is because they are considered to have come through Korea.
This is because they are considered to have come through Korea.

sen.j: だが、実際の起源はインドという説が有力である。
sen.e: But the leading theory is that Komainu has Indian origin.
But the leading theory is that Komainu has an Indian origin.
But the leading theory is that Komainu has an Indian origin.

sen.j: また、朝鮮に狛犬の文化は無く、高麗とは音から来る当て字で「高麗の犬」という意味ではなく、あくまで「狛犬（こまいぬ）」という想像上の神獣であり、同じく対になる獅子も当時の日本人はライオンを見たことが無い。
sen.e: There is no culture of Komainu in Korea in the first place, and the Chinese character, "高麗", has been used just to borrow the sound; Komainu never means a dog from Korea, but is an imaginary divine beast, and Shishi, the other in pair, is a lion, which had never been witnessed by the-then Japanese.

In the first place, there is no cultural history of Komainu in Korea, and the Chinese character, "高麗", has been used just to borrow the sound; Komainu was never meant to be a dog from Korea, but was thought to be an imaginary divine beast, and Shishi, the other in pairs, is a lion, which had never been witnessed by the Japanese at that time.
sen.cmt: sentence restructured, words added for clarity
sen.e: In the first place, there is no cultural history of Komainu in Korea, and the Chinese character, "高麗", has been used just to borrow the sound; Komainu was never meant to be a dog from Korea, but was thought to be an imaginary divine beast, and Shishi, the other in pairs, is a lion, which had never been witnessed by the Japanese at that time.

sen.j: そのため、これも獅子＝ライオンではなく「獅子（しし）」という神獣であると考えられる。
sen.e: This leads us to conclude that the Shishi is not a lion, but a divine beast named "Shishi".
This leads us to conclude that the Shishi is not a lion, but a mythical divine beast named "Shishi".
This leads us to conclude that the Shishi is not a lion, but a mythical divine beast named "Shishi".

sen.j: 一般的には、向かって右側の像は「阿形（あぎょう）」で、角はなく口は開いている。
sen.e: Typically, the statue placed on your right is Agyo, which has no horn with its mouth open.
Typically, the statue on your right is an Agyo, which has no horns and has its mouth open.
Typically, the statue on your right is an Agyo, which has no horns and has its mouth open.

sen.j: そして、向かって左側の像は「吽形（うんぎょう）」で、1本の角があり口を閉じている。
sen.e: The statue on your left is Ungyo, which has one horn with its mouth closed.
The statue on your left is Ungyo, which has one horn with its mouth closed.
The statue on your left is Ungyo, which has one horn, with its mouth closed.
sen.cmt: 意味を明確にするために、コンマを付加。 -> “which has one horn, with its mouth closed.” 角に口があるのではないから。

sen.j: 両方の像を合わせて「狛犬」と称することが多いが、厳密には、角のない方の像を「獅子」、角のある方の像を「狛犬」と言い、1対で「獅子狛犬」と称するのが正しいとされている。
sen.e: We often call them both "Komainu" without telling them apart, but more strictly speaking, they should be called "Shishi/komainu" as the statue without a horn is called "Shishi" and the other with a horn "Komainu".

We often call them both "Komainu" without distinquishing them from each other, but more strictly speaking, they should be called "Shishi/komainu" as the statue without any horns is called "Shishi" and the other with a horn "Komainu".

We often call them both "Komainu" without distinguishing them from each other, but more strictly speaking, they should be called "Shishi/komainu" as the statue without any horns is called "Shishi" and the other with a horn "Komainu".

sen.j: 昭和時代以降に作られた物は、左右共に角が無い物が多い。
sen.e: The statues of Komainu built from the Showa era onwards do not have a horn regardless of on which side they are placed.
The Komainu statues, created from the Showa era onwards, do not have a horn no matter on which side they are placed.
The Komainu statues, created from the Showa era onwards, do not have a horn no matter on which side they are placed.

sen.j: これらは本来は「獅子」と呼ぶべきものである。
sen.e: These should be primarily called "Shishi".
These should be primarily called "Shishi".
These should be primarily called "Shishi".

sen.j: 各地の寺社境内で見かける狛犬には石製や銅製のものが多いが、神社本殿内に置かれたものには木造の場合もある。
sen.e: Although Komainu seen in the grounds of temples or shrines are often made of stone or bronze, some placed inside the main shrine are made of wood.
Although Komainu seen on the grounds of temples or shrines are often made of stone or bronze, some placed inside the main shrine are made of wood.
sen.cmt: "on" is the correct word unless the Komainu is buried in the ground
sen.e: Although Komainu seen on the grounds of temples or shrines are often made of stone or bronze, some placed inside the main shrine are made of wood.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳巻第46の左右衛門府に、大儀日にじ像を会員門左に置き終了時に本府に返却する。
sen.e: According to a description of Emonfu of the Left and Right (the offices that safeguarded palace gates) in Volume 46 of Engishiki jinmyocho (a list of shrines), Komainu was placed on the left side of the Kaiin-mon gate on a Taigibi day (a day of an imperial ceremony) and returned to Emonfu when the ceremony was over.
sen.cmt: 「会員門」が不明です。「じ像」が不明です。左側に置かれた狛犬が何体かが不明ですが、一体と考えて、単数形で表現しています。
sen.e: According to a description of Emonfu of the Left and Right (the offices that safeguarded palace gates) in Volume 46 of Engishiki jinmyocho (a list of shrines), Komainu were placed on the left side of the Kaiin-mon gate on a Taigibi day (a day of an imperial ceremony) and returned to Emonfu when the ceremony was over.

According to a description of Saemonfu of the Left and Right (the offices that safeguarded palace gates) in Volume 46 of Engishiki jinmyocho (a list of shrines), Komainu were placed on the left side of the Kaiin-mon gate on a Taigibi day (a day of an imperial ceremony) and returned to Saemonfu when the ceremony was over.

sen.j: 右府は右に置くと記述されるように平安時代にさかのぼる。
sen.e: This also suggests that Emonfu of the Right placed the statue on the right side of the gate; all of these signify that the Komainu dates back to the Heian era.
sen.cmt: 「右府」は右衛門府と考えています。また、何体の狛犬が右側に置かれたかが、不明ですが、一体と考えて単数計で表現しています。
sen.e: This also suggests that Emonfu of the Right placed the statue on the right side of the gate; all of these signify that the Komainu dates back to the Heian era.
This also suggests that Emonfu of the Right placed the statue on the right side of the gate; all of these signify that the Komainu dates back to the Heian era.

sen.j: 当時の獅子狛犬像としては、奈良・薬師寺の鎮守八幡宮の木像（重要文化財）が著名である。
sen.e: Among the Shishi/komainu statues of that time, the ones in the Chinju Hachimangu shrine of the Yakushi-ji temple in Nara are well-known; they are made of wood and have been designated important cultural assets.

Among the Shishi/komainu statues of that time, the ones in the Chinju Hachimangu shrine of the Yakushi-ji temple in Nara are well-known; they are made of wood and have been designated important cultural assets.

Among the Shishi/komainu statues of that time, the ones in the Chinju Hachimangu shrine of the Yakushi-ji temple in Nara are well-known; they are made of wood and have been designated important cultural assets.

sen.j: ただし、この薬師寺像は、左右とも角がなく、正式には「獅子1対」と呼ぶべきであろう。
sen.e: However, as neither of the statues have a horn, they should be more appropriately called "Shishi pair".
However, as neither of the statues have a horn, they should be more appropriately called "Shishi pair".
However, as neither of the statues have a horn, they should be more appropriately called "Shishi pair".

sen.j: 重要文化財指定の狛犬は他に、滋賀・大宝神社、京都・高山寺、広島・厳島神社などのものが著名である。
sen.e: Other Komainu statues that have been designated important cultural assets include those of the Daiho Jinja shrine in Shiga, Kozan-ji temple in Kyoto, and Itsukushima Jinja shrine in Hiroshima.

Other Komainu statues that have been designated important cultural assets include those of the Daiho Jinja shrine in Shiga, the Kozan-ji temple in Kyoto, and the Itsukushima Jinja shrine in Hiroshima.

Other Komainu statues that have been designated important cultural assets include those of the Daiho Jinja shrine in Shiga, the Kozan-ji temple in Kyoto, and the Itsukushima Jinja shrine in Hiroshima.

sen.j: 狛犬は中国や大韓民国にも同様の物があるが、阿吽（あ・うん）の形があるのは日本で多く見られる特徴である。
sen.e: Although similar statues are found in China and Korea, those that come in a pair of A-un (Agyo and Ugyo) are typically seen in Japan.
Although similar statues are found in China and Korea, those that come in a pair of A-un (Agyo and Ugyo) are typically seen in Japan.
Although similar statues are found in China and Korea, those that come in a pair of A-un (Agyo and Ungyo) are typically seen in Japan.

sen.j: これは金剛力士の影響を受けたと考えられ平安時代には既に定着していた。
sen.e: This may be because they were under the influence of Kongo rikishi (a guardian deity of Buddhism) and the A-un style had already become norm by the end of the Heian era.
This may be because they were under the influence of Kongo rikishi (a guardian deity of Buddhism) and the A-un style had already become the norm by the end of the Heian era.
This may be because they were under the influence of Kongo rikishi (a guardian deity of Buddhism) and the A-un style had already become the norm by the end of the Heian era.

sen.j: ただし、日本の狛犬は近世から現代にかけて、各地の寺社に膨大な数が造られており、形態にもさまざまなバリエーションがある。
sen.e: However, from the modern ages to the present ages in Japan, the vast number of Komainu have been built in various forms and shapes.
However, from modern to the present age in Japan, the vast number of Komainu have been made in various forms and shapes.
sen.cmt: "built" conjures up scenes of building construction, objects of art are "made," "created," "carved," or "sculptured"
sen.e: However, from modern to the present age in Japan, the vast number of Komainu have been made in various forms and shapes.

sen.j: 例えば、イノシシや龍、キツネの形の像が同様の役割を果たしていることもある。
sen.e: For example, the statues of other animals like boars, dragons, or foxes play a similar role as well.
For example, the statues of other animals like boars, dragons, or foxes, play a similar role as well.
For example, the statues of other animals like boars, dragons, or foxes, play a similar role as well.

sen.j: これらをあわせて神道では神使（しんし）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In Shinto, all of these animals are called Shinshi (the messengers of the god).
In Shinto, all of these animals are called Shinshi (the messengers of the god).
In Shinto, all of these animals are called Shinshi (the messengers of the god).

sen.j: この神使は神社（祀られる神）によって特定の動物が採用されている場合が少なからずある。
sen.e: Not a few shrines (or gods enshrined) have adopted specific animals as their Shinshi.
Many shrines (or enshrined gods) have adopted specific animals as their Shinshi.
sen.cmt: awkward beginning and word order changed
sen.e: Many shrines (or enshrined gods) have adopted specific animals as their Shinshi.

sen.j: 稲荷神社に狐、春日神社に鹿、弁財天には蛇などが代表的な物である。
sen.e: Most notable are foxes in the Inari-jinja shrine, deer in the Kasuga-jinja shrine, and snakes in Benzaiten.
Most notable are foxes in the Inari-jinja shrine, deer in the Kasuga-jinja shrine, and snakes in Benzaiten.
Most notable are foxes in the Inari-jinja shrine, deer in the Kasuga-jinja shrine, and snakes in Benzaiten.

sen.j: また、土地の伝承などに基づくものもある。
sen.e: Some are based on local lore.
Some are based on local lore.
Some are based on local lore.

sen.j: 例えば、遠野常堅寺では河童伝説に基づき狛犬の場所に河童像が置かれている、など。
sen.e: For example, at the Joken-ji temple in Tono, the statues of kappa (a legendary creature, assumed to carry a plate on its head) are placed in the place where Komainu are supposed to be placed, following the local legend of the kappa.

For example, at the Joken-ji temple in Tono, the statues of kappa (a legendary creature, assumed to carry a dish filled with water on its head) are standing where Komainu are supposed to be, following the local legend of the kappa.
sen.cmt: revised, words added, deleted for clarity and readability
sen.e: For example, at the Joken-ji temple in Tono, the statues of kappa (a legendary creature, assumed to carry a dish filled with water on its head) are standing where Komainu are supposed to be, following the local legend of the kappa.

sen.j: 一般的には、守るべき寺社に背を向ける形で置かれる。
sen.e: They are typically placed with their back against the temples or shrines that they are supposed to protect.
They are typically placed with their backs against the temples or shrines that they are supposed to protect.
They are typically placed with their backs against the temples or shrines that they are supposed to protect.

sen.j: だが、まれに寺社の方を向いている物もある。
sen.e: Exceptionally, however, some are placed facing towards the temples or shrines.
In some exceptions, however, some are placed facing towards the temples or shrines.
In some exceptions, however, some are placed facing towards the temples or shrines.

sen.j: また、稀に対をなしていないものも存在する。
sen.e: Some do not come in pair although they are few in number.
Some do not come in pairs although they are few in number.
Some do not come in pairs although they are few in number.

sen.j: 左右の狛犬をして夫婦であると主張する寺社も存在する。
sen.e: Some temples or shrines consider Komainu on your right and your left as a couple.
Some temples or shrines consider Komainu on your right and your left as a couple.
Some temples or shrines consider Komainu on your right and your left as a couple.

sen.j: 「狛犬が獅子の姿形をしている以上、たてがみを持つのは当然雄である。
sen.e: As long as Komainu are in the shape of Shishi (lion), the one that has mane is no doubt male.
As long as Komainu are in the shape of Shishi (liondog), the one that has mane is no doubt male.
As long as Komainu are in the shape of Shishi (liondog), the one that has mane is no doubt male.

sen.j: つまり、狛犬同士がつがいとなることはあり得ないため、生物学的にはこの主張は誤り」とする見解がある。
sen.e: Some insist that the above view is wrong as it is biologicallyimpossible for two Komainu to make a couple.
Some insist that the above view is wrong as it is biologicallyimpossible for two Komainu to make a couple.
Some insist that the above view is wrong as it is biologicallyimpossible for two Komainu to make a couple.

sen.j: 一方で、「子狛犬あるいは子獅子をあやしているものや授乳しているものもあるため、夫婦で正しい」とする見解もある。
sen.e: On the other hand, some support the view that they are a couple as some breast-feed or pacify their child Komainu or Shishi.
On the other hand, some support the view that they are a couple as some breast-feed or pacify their Komainu puppies or Shishi.
sen.cmt: child is not used for animals
sen.e: On the other hand, some support the view that they are a couple as some breast-feed or pacify their Komainu or Shishi puppies.
sen.cmt: puppiesが狛犬と獅子の両方を受けるようにしました。

sen.j: 厳密に正しい・正しくないで争うことに意味はないが、夫婦肯定説・夫婦否定説の両説がそれぞれ主張されている。
sen.e: There is no use arguing over which is right, but the fact is that there are two theories; one is to support the view that a pair of Komainu is a couple and the other is to oppose to it.
There is no use arguing over which is right, but the fact is that there are two theories; one is to support the view that a pair of Komainu is a couple and the other is to oppose to it.
There is no use arguing over which is right, but the fact is that there are two theories; one is to support the view that a pair of Komainu is a couple and the other is to oppose to it.

tit.j: 狛犬以外の想像上の獣の像

sen.j: カイチ
sen.e: Kaichi (Haetae)
Kaichi (Haetae)
Kaichi (Haetae)

sen.j: シーサー
sen.e: Shisa
Shisa
Shisa

sen.j: ケルベロス
sen.e: Cerberus
Cerberus
Cerberus

sen.j: スフィンクス
sen.e: Sphinx
